title: [HOLD for #27392] [$500] iOS - Profile - Local time does not show the hour after GMT for users in GMT+n time zone

labels.name: External
labels.description: Added to denote the issue can be worked on by a contributor

labels.name: Bug
labels.description: Something is broken. Auto assigns a BugZero manager.

comments.body: Triggered auto assignment to @sakluger (`Bug`), see https://stackoverflow.com/c/expensify/questions/14418 for more details.

### Bug0 Triage Checklist ([Main S/O](https://stackoverflowteams.com/c/expensify/questions/14418))

- [x] This "bug" occurs on a supported platform (ensure `Platforms` in OP are ✅)
- [ ] This bug is not a duplicate report (check [E/App issues](https://github.com/Expensify/App/issues) and [#expensify-bugs](https://expensify.slack.com/archives/C049HHMV9SM))
    - If it is, comment with a link to the original report, close the issue and add any novel details to the original issue instead
- [ ] This bug is reproducible using the reproduction steps in the OP. [S/O](https://stackoverflowteams.com/c/expensify/questions/14418#:~:text=The%20bug%20is%20reproducible)
    - If the reproduction steps are clear and you're unable to reproduce the bug, check with the reporter and QA first, then close the issue.
    - If the reproduction steps aren't clear and you determine the correct steps, please update the OP.
- [ ] This issue is filled out as thoroughly and clearly as possible
    - Pay special attention to the title, results, platforms where the bug occurs, and if the bug happens on staging/production.
- [ ] I have reviewed and subscribed to the linked Slack conversation to ensure Slack/Github stay in sync
Triggered auto assignment to Contributor-plus team member for initial proposal review - @thesahindia (`External`)

## Proposal

### Please re-state the problem that we are trying to solve in this issue.
The local time shows only GMT and it is missing the hours behind GMT (GMT+n).

### What is the root cause of that problem?
The approach to get timezone abbreviation we're using in `getZoneAbbreviation` relies on the Intl API under the hood, which might give different results for different platforms, on iOS it doesn't seem that Intl API supports the abbreviate timezone format, so it always return as 'GMT'.

### What changes do you think we should make in order to solve the problem?
<!-- DO NOT POST CODE DIFFS -->
We already have our list of defined timezones [here](https://github.com/Expensify/App/blob/0cca90ab9aa7fd9467ef45ca35c4d0ad3c3334ae/src/TIMEZONES.ts#L2), we can transform it to a list of objects
```
{
    name: 'Asia/Singapore',
    abbreviation: 'SGT' // or 'GMT+8' depending on which format we want
}
```
And use it to retrieve the correct timezone abbreviation. The abbreviations can be easily retrieved by getting public lists/international standard, just like how we construct the timezone list in the first place.

If for some reasons the timezone returned is not in our timezone list, then we can fallback to the current approach/or return default `GMT+...` format.

### What alternative solutions did you explore? (Optional)
NA

<!---
ATTN: Contributor+

You are the first line of defense in making sure every proposal has a clear and easily understood problem with a "root cause". Do not approve any proposals that lack a satisfying explanation to the first two prompts. It is CRITICALLY important that we understand the root cause at a minimum even if the solution doesn't directly address it. When we avoid this step we can end up solving the wrong problems entirely or just writing hacks and workarounds.

Instructions for how to review a proposal:

1. Address each contributor proposal one at a time and address each part of the question one at a time e.g. if a solution looks acceptable, but the stated problem is not clear then you should provide feedback and make suggestions to improve each prompt before moving on to the next. Avoid responding to all sections of a proposal at once. Move from one question to the next each time asking the contributor to "Please update your original proposal and tag me again when it's ready for review".

2. Limit excessive conversation and moderate issues to keep them on track. If someone is doing any of the following things please kindly and humbly course-correct them:

- Posting PRs.
- Posting large multi-line diffs (this is basically a PR).
- Skipping any of the required questions.
- Not using the proposal template at all.
- Suggesting that an existing issue is related to the current issue before a problem or root cause has been established.
- Excessively wordy explanations.

3. Choose the first proposal that has a reasonable answer to all the required questions.
-->

`date-fns-tz` already handles this for us: https://github.com/Expensify/App/blob/281a940cfa1fd0c4286d3f1cb95acadc4ec736fc/src/libs/DateUtils.ts#L204-L206 I'm seeing the user in question doesn't have a timezone set, so it defaults to my local time. Maybe a backend issue with returning automatic timezones? I manually set a test account to Europe/Paris and it works as expected:

# Proposal
## Please re-state the problem that we are trying to solve in this issue.

iOS - Profile - Local time does not show the hour after GMT for users in GMT+n time zone

## What is the root cause of that problem?

The problem is most likely related to the implementation of the `formatInTimeZone` method in mobile applications
Which cannot get the value we need
However by testing other methods we can get the local time without any problems

## What changes do you think we should make in order to solve the problem?

Since we have many other methods
we can try using the `format ` method and update this function

https://github.com/Expensify/App/blob/0cca90ab9aa7fd9467ef45ca35c4d0ad3c3334ae/src/libs/DateUtils.ts#L204-L206


Like 

```
function getZoneAbbreviation(datetime: string, selectedTimezone: SelectedTimezone): string {
    return format(datetime, 'zzz') ({timeZone: selectedTimezone} - optional);
}
```

this method correctly returns the data we need

Alternatively, we can use this method for IOS only

## What alternative solutions did you explore? (Optional)
Also we can use `getTimezoneOffset`
Witch returns the time zone offset from UTC time in milliseconds for IANA time zones as well as other time zone offset string formats.
I won't be able to take this.
@dukenv0307 Thanks for the proposal. Your RCA is correct. However the solution does not seem to be the best to do here.
@ZhenjaHorbach Thanks for the proposal. Your RCA is not complete.

I have been checking this and it's indeed related to `Intl.DateTimeFormat` poor support on Native (especially iOS for this case). The easiest solution is to use a polyfill. That's also the [library](https://github.com/marnusw/date-fns-tz/) suggestion 

> Modern browsers and Node.js all support the [necessary features](https://developer.mozilla.org/en-US/docs/Web/JavaScript/Reference/Global_Objects/DateTimeFormat#Browser_compatibility), and for those that don't a [polyfill](https://formatjs.io/docs/polyfills/intl-datetimeformat) can be used.


I have also found that we have a related issue https://github.com/Expensify/App/issues/27392 and @tienifr's [solution](https://github.com/Expensify/App/issues/27392#issuecomment-1791126160) includes the polyfill solution (step 1).
With that ^ being said I think we should put this one on hold for https://github.com/Expensify/App/issues/27392. cc @sakluger

📣 @s77rt 🎉 An offer has been automatically sent to your Upwork account for the Contributor role 🎉 Thanks for contributing to the Expensify app!

[Offer link](https://www.upwork.com/nx/wm/offer/27793675)
[Upwork job](https://www.upwork.com/jobs/~0143fc4857e82b1840)
Please accept the offer and leave a comment on the Github issue letting us know when we can expect a PR to be ready for review 🧑‍💻
Keep in mind: [Code of Conduct](https://github.com/Expensify/App/blob/main/CODE_OF_CONDUCT.md) | [Contributing](https://github.com/Expensify/App/blob/main/contributingGuides/CONTRIBUTING.md) 📖
Thanks @s77rt! I'll put this one on hold, hopefully https://github.com/Expensify/App/issues/27392 fixes it.

@dukenv0307 Indeed the passed datetime is useless since we are only extracting the time zone, any datetime will work just fine. But the current way we are doing it is still the correct way, although it seems that the timezone abbreviation is a 1:1 map it could be complex to maintain. More importantly the list you are suggesting to add is already available in the js engines so it would be a waste to add it again as it will just increase the App bundle size. iOS is the only affected platform where a polyfill is needed but I can see this getting fixed in the future to remove that polyfill and relay only on the Intl API.
